questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains an Active Directory forest. The forest contains the servers in the following table.
//IMG//

The dmz.litware.com domain contains mail-enabled user accounts but does not contain any Exchange servers.
You plan to replace the existing Exchange servers with new servers that have Exchange Server 2019 installed.
You need to extend the schema and prepare the Active Directory domains.
What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
correct : computer needs to be a member of the same Active Directory domain and site as the schema master

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/plan-and-deploy/prepare-ad-and-domains?view=exchserver-2019

It is correct, requirements to apply both of them:
/PrepareSchema: The computer needs to be a member of the same Active Directory domain and site as the schema master.
/PrepareDomain: You need to run this command for each Active Directory domain where you'll install an Exchange server or where mail-enabled users will be located.

questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy Microsoft Exchange Server 2019.
You need to verify whether the Active Directory environment is prepared for the deployment.
What are two methods to verify whether the Active Directory environment is prepared? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct. when you prepare AD and domains for Exchange, you can validate work is complete checking both of them: ADSI Edit and Exchange setup log.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/plan-and-deploy/prepare-ad-and-domains?view=exchserver-2019#how-do-you-know-this-worked
D and E - both shows ad forest functional level and information on DCs.
D: is a right answer for sure

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains the subnets shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You need to prevent users in the London office from accessing the Exchange admin center (EAC).
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The answer is wrong. If you look carefully it says "except from london subnet". So you should deny, not permit access to the other subnets

comments.content: The answer is correct, you allow access to EAC but deny to london subnet

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
The recovery options for a user named User1 are configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Glad I finally found a correct representation for the answer to this specific question. I've seen this question with the second answer showing as "an administrator or User1 can recover the message without". Which makes no sense at all. Why do people charge for premium files with obvious wrong answers???

Regarding the second one ;

In Exchange Server, single item recovery is disabled when a mailbox is created. If single item recovery is enabled, messages that are permanently deleted (purged) by the user are retained in the Recoverable Items folder of the mailbox until the deleted item retention period expires. This lets an administrator recover messages purged by the user before the deleted item retention period expires.

Here single item recovery is disabled so the only option is to restore the purged mail from a backup for DB where MAilbox hosted

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/recipients-in-exchange-online/manage-user-mailboxes/enable-or-disable-single-item-recovery

- Soft Delete: The item is moved to Recoverable Items folder
- Hard Delete: The item is deleted (purged) from Recoverable Items folder

Hence, since Single Item Recover isn't enabled, items that are purged from the Recoverable Items folder can only be recovered from a backup of the mailbox database.
When an email is hard deleted it is still in the Recover Deleted Items folder so the user should be able to restore from that themselves.

choices.D: Remove Mail1, Mail2, and Mail3 from EX01.
choices.C: Suspend the replication of Mail1, Mail2, and Mail3 on EX01.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You have a database availability group (DAG) that contains the members and databases shown in the following table.
//IMG//

EX01 fails and cannot be repaired within an acceptable timeframe.
You plan to replace EX01 with a new DAG member named EX05. EX05 will host the same databases as EX01.
What should you do first?

comments.content: Before removing server from DAG you have to remove DB copies from server....same link for referal :)
